data.title: 95-year-old Richmond resident refurbishes 83-year-old bike
data.meta_description: 83 years after being gifted a bike for his twelfth birthday, this South Richmond resident decided to take it for a spin again.
data.text:
On Dec. 28, 1940, a 12-year-old Bill MacMillan walked down the stairs on his birthday to find a brand-new 1940 Western Flyer bicycle waiting for him in his Woodland Heights home. His feet could barely reach the pedals, but he taught himself to ride it and, within a few weeks, it took him everywhere.

Two weeks ago, 83 years after he was first given the bike, MacMillan wheeled the rusty bicycle out his basement, repaired it and took it for a ride.

“A couple of weeks ago, I decided I would get it out of the basement,” he said. “I pumped up the tires ... and I took it out and rode.”

Because of the bike’s age, MacMillan said, riding it for distances longer than a couple of blocks is difficult. But he still bikes often around his South Richmond neighborhood.

“At 95, I am still riding on a 21-speed bike ... I still ride that one to the grocery store,” he said.

MacMillan said he also uses his bike to go to the drugstore and run other errands at least twice a week. To carry his groceries, he installed a basket on the back of his bike, as well as a rearview mirror for road safety.

A Virginia National Guard veteran and Philip Morris USA retiree, MacMillan has been repairing bikes since he was 15 years old.

“About once a year, I would take that bicycle completely apart, clean the parts and put new grease in it,” he said. “And that’s probably why it has lasted so long.”

In addition to repairing his own bikes, family, friends and neighbors sometimes ask him to repair their bikes and lawn mowers.

Listen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts

MacMillan said he has a “mechanical brain” and taught himself most of what he knows.

“People give me bikes to repair,” he said. “And they don’t pick them up and, in other words, I’ve got a lot of bikes in my basement that I have just found or people have given to me.”

Two of MacMillan’s daughters, Pamela MacMillan and Cheryl MacMillan, said he has always been active.

“He was always engaged,” Pamela said. “He always wanted to go camping, do things, very active. He was never a sit-on-the-couch kind of dad.”

Cheryl said that in addition to repairing bikes for other children in their neighborhood, her father once built wooden stilts for she and her sisters to play with and taught them to swim as children in the James River.

“The James River was our playground,” Cheryl said. “He had a rock ... it was the only place where you could stand on a rock and dive into the water. But the current was really strong, so you had to start swimming immediately upstream. He taught us to do that when we were just little kids.”

In addition to biking, Cheryl said MacMillan dances regularly, at the American Legion on Fridays and at the East Moose Lodge in Mechanicsville on Saturdays.

In the past, MacMillan has ridden unicycles, sledded, ice-skated and been at the top of a waterski pyramid.

Pamela said his active lifestyle acts as a “buffer” to aging.

“He’s always been very active and kind of atypical,” she said. “He was unusual. ... There’s nothing superficial about him.”
